title-group.subtitle: Report of a Case and Literature Review

author-notes.corresp: Ibrahim O. Bello, Department of Oral Medicine and Diagnostic Sciences, College of Dentistry, King Saud University, P.O. Box 60169, Riyadh, 11545, Saudi Arabia Email: ibello@ksu.edu.sa

abstract.p: Peripheral dentinogenic ghost cell tumor is a rare tumor with only 24 cases previously described in the English literature. The majority of cases have been reported to occur in the anterior part of the jaws. A case occurring in posterior (molar region) of the mandible in a 75-year-old edentulous woman is reported. The patient presented with a nodular swelling in the left mandible that showed erosion (saucerization) of the underlying bone radiographically. On microscopy, the tumor showed mainly solid epithelial islands resembling ameloblastoma in fibrous connective tissue. The islands were associated with ghost cells and dysplastic dentin. This report includes the clinical, radiographic, and microscopic features of the patient, in addition to the review of the English literature on the tumor.

body.p: Since it was first comprehensively described in 1961 by Gorlin et al,1 the diverse histologic and behavioral features of benign calcifying odontogenic cyst (COC) has created a nomenclature difficulty for oral pathologists.2-4 Since 1992, the World Health Organization (WHO) classification of oral tumors attempted to simplify the nomenclature by reclassifying COC as a tumor comprising a cystic variant (calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor, CCOT) and a neoplastic variant (dentinogenic ghost cell tumor, DGCT), both of which can arise intraosseously (central) or extraosseously (peripheral).5,6 This classification has not gained a unanimous acceptance, as most researchers still favor the dualistic concept of the CCOT as a cyst and DGCT as a tumor.7

The DGCT is a locally invasive neoplasm characterized by ameloblastoma-like islands in a mature connective tissue stroma associated with the presence of aberrant keratinization in the form of ghost cells and varying amounts of dysplastic dentin.5 The central variant is said to be aggressive whereas the peripheral variant is less aggressive.8 Very few cases of peripheral dentinogenic ghost cell tumor (PDGCT) have been reported in the English literature. From these reports, PDGCT seems to be slightly more common in males, affects both jaws almost equally but with a striking predilection for the anterior part and can occur at any age, but usually in those older than 50 years. In this report, a well-documented case of PDGCT with complete clinical, radiographic, and histological findings is presented. The nature, clinical features, and histopathological features of the lesion are also discussed along with a review of the English literature.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 75-year-old edentulous woman was referred to the Department of Oral Medicine and Diagnostic Sciences of the King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia for the evaluation of a reddish, nodular swelling involving the left posterior edentulous ridge (first molar region) of the mandible. Swelling was reportedly of 3 months’ duration. There was no previous eventful medical history. Patient has been wearing an overdenture for an unknown period of time. Clinical examination revealed a tender, firm, broad-based sessile soft tissue nodule with ulcerated surface measuring approximately 1.5 cm in its widest diameter (Figure 1A). No fever, malaise, or lymphadenopathy was present. A periapical radiograph showed erosion (saucerization) of the underlying bone (Figure 1B). The lesion was completely excised under local anesthesia and submitted for histological examination. The patient was no longer seen after a year of follow-up.

caption.p: (A) Patient at presentation. A reddish, nodular, ulcerated lesion on the crest of the alveolar ridge of posterior mandible. (B) Periapical radiograph shows the lesion has caused a saucerization of the underlying bone

sec.p: Histology revealed an unencapsulated soft tissue mass comprising multiple solid islands of odontogenic epithelium in a fibrous connective tissue stroma (Figure 2A and B). The islands closely resemble follicles of ameloblastoma with palisading and reverse polarity of the nuclei of the peripheral columnar cells enclosing more loosely arranged stellate reticulum-like central cells (Figure 2C and D). In a few areas, these islands show cystic degeneration (Figure 2B). Most of the islands contain pale, eosinophilic ghost cells devoid of nuclei or with faint nuclear outline within the central portion. In areas where the ghost cells are predominant, the peripheral cells of the islands are cuboidal or fibroblastoid with loss of palisading (Figure 3A and B). There were many irregular foci of tissue resembling dentin (dentinoid) sometimes in relation to the ghost cells or around the epithelial islands (juxtaepithelial dentinoid; Figure 3A and B). Multinucleated giant cells were observed in areas where the ghost cells are in direct contact with the stroma, as well as many scattered foci of dystrophic calcification (Figure 3C and D). The overlying epithelium was generally unremarkable except for focal areas of ulceration and continuation of tumor with the basal cells of the overlying epithelium (Figure 2B). van Gieson and Verhoeff–van Gieson staining of the tumor clearly differentiated the ghost cells from the dentinoid with the ghost cells taking a yellow color and the dentinoid and osteodentin taking a pink or dark reddish color, respectively (Figure 4A and B). The Verhoeff–van Gieson stain better demonstrates the calcification occurring in the dentinoid as it becomes darker with increasing mineralization.

caption.p: (A) Unencapsulated solid tumor in the connective tissue comprising ghost cells and dentinoid (hematoxylin and eosin [H&E], original magnification ×12.5). (B) An area of tumor connected with the overlying epithelium, and displaying some cystic changes (H&E, ×12.5). (C) Another area displaying ameloblastoma-like solid islands with central ghost cells (H&E, ×50). (D) Enlarged view of the island in (C) showing palisading with reverse polarization of nuclei of the peripheral cells and the loosely arranged stellate reticulum-like central cells. Ghost cell changes are evident in the central cells (H&E, ×100)

(A) Foci of osteodentin (arrow; hematoxylin and eosin [H&E], ×12.5). (B) Foci of dentinoid associated with the ghost cells and epithelial islands (arrow; H&E, ×50). (C) Multinucleated giant cell closely related to ghost cells (arrow; H&E, ×100). (D) Foci of dystrophic calcification (arrows, H&E, ×50)

(A) van Gieson stain differentiates ghost cells (yellow) from dentinoid and osteodentin (pink; ×50). (B) Verhoeff–van Gieson also similarly differentiates ghost cells from dentinoid with osteodentin appearing darker than dentinoid. These stains underline the collagenous nature of the dentinoid (×50)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: PDGCT is a rare tumor with only 24 cases previously reported (Table 1). It has been observed in patients over a wide age range (13-92 years) although more than 65% have occurred in patients older than 50 years. The mean age of the previously reported cases was 59 years. It is slightly more common in males and affects the mandible more than the maxilla. It is usually restricted to the gingiva in dentate patients and alveolar mucosa in edentulous patients and varies in size from 0.5 to 4 cm. Saucerization of the underlying bone is observed in about 20% of cases.5 Many cases are probably diagnosed as peripheral ameloblastoma.9 The preferred mode of treatment for PDGCT is conservative excision. There has been no previous report of recurrence after treatment.

caption.p: Reported Cases of Peripheral Dentinogenic Ghost Cell Tumor

sec.p: This report presents the case of a 75-year-old Saudi female with the classic clinical, radiographic, and histological features of PDGCT as described by the WHO.5 The only relatively different feature of this patient is the posterior mandibular presentation of the tumor. Case reports from the English literature (Table 1) have shown that this tumor is more commonly seen in the anterior part of the jaws, as only 3 (20%) cases out of 15 with well-defined locations have occurred posteriorly. With regard to jaw affectation, the tumor has a definite predilection for the lower jaw. Only 6 cases (26%) out of the 23 with documented sites have occurred in the maxilla. The role of trauma or irritation as an etiologic factor of the tumor in this case was also considered. The patient was a denture wearer (used overdentures) of an unknown duration. Although Hong et al16 did not specifically emphasize the role of trauma, they reported 8 cases of which 5 subjects (63%) were denture wearers, all of which occurred in the mandibular edentulous mucosa.

PDGCT, like its intraosseous counterpart (DGCT), exhibits a histological picture comprising ameloblastoma-like epithelium in a fibrous tissue stroma with ghost cell changes in the epithelial islands particularly within the centrally located stellate reticulum-like cells along with juxtaepithelial dentinoid, which may be undergoing calcification. The ghost cells are transformed epithelial cells, although their nature is still poorly understood. Many investigators have considered them to represent abnormal or incomplete keratinization of odontogenic epithelial cells23-25 or just degenerating epithelial cells.4 Hong et al,16 after considering their general histological features in addition to their minimal immunohistochemical reaction to cytokeratin, concluded that they are probably a product of coagulative necrosis. Other workers have considered them to be metasplastic epithelial cells, which become secondarily calcified as a response to ischemia.26,27

The dentinoid seen in DGCTs (also seen in some other odontogenic tumors or cysts) has been described as an osteoid-like atypical dysplastic dentin that contains cells and collagen but devoid of the normal tubular structure of dentin.19 Some investigators believe that the dentinoid is of inflammatory origin suggesting that the ghost cells induce granulation tissue to lay down osteoid that may subsequently calcify.10 This would not explain the fact that most juxtaepithelial dentinoid are usually seen without any associated granulation tissue. Others have suggested that it represents a metaplastic change in the connective tissue without the participation of granulation tissue.28 Some workers also believe that the dentinoid is a result of the inductive effect of the odontogenic epithelial component of the tumor.21,29 The latter suggestions may explain the origin of most of the juxtaepithelial dentinoid as commonly seen in DGCTs. The connection between the basal cells of the overlying epithelium and the tumor cells suggests the histogenesis of this case from the overlying epithelium.11 In cases where there is no connection with the overlying epithelium, an origin from the remnants of the dental lamina (rest of Serres) has been suggested.11

In summary, we have presented a case of PDGCT in a female elderly patient. The age of the patient, the size of this lesion, the site affected, the saucerization of the underlying bone, as well the lack of recurrence after treatment are all in agreement with the majority of previous reports. The histological picture is basically as described by the WHO.5

ack.p: We thank Ms Jeanette Quinsay for her technical assistance.
